Campus Safety
Greek Life
Clubs and Activities
Great for these types of students
Share any unusual traditions or locations on campus
Bang for the buck
What to do for fun
Food and Dining
Dorm Life
Academic Rigor
Tips for prospective students
In three sentences
Comments

Our own UVU police are always available and well lit paths help avoid problems for late night students. The Campus is always crawling with students that care all day as we have many commuters and night students.
As a newer university the Greek are up and coming. Our Sororities and Fraternities are committed to breaking the old ideal of hazed and unappreciated students.
Again Utah Valley University boasts hundreds of the most involved students making up at least 100 different clubs all hosting year round activities.

Everyone. UVU has only recently attained University status, as such welcomes students looking for lower priced schooling with upper level academic standards. Many commuters choose UVU for its ideal location right of the highway.
True Wolverine each semester always has a great turnout. The UVU students' life can be full of Wolverine traditions.
UVU offers students the Starving Student Card that provides great deals and promos, saving each student hundreds of dollars.
Everything outdoors. Provo Canyon hosts climbers, walkers, biking, longboarding, and more. There are numerous ski/snowboard resorts nearby with shuttles and everyday deals.
There are always promotions and deals in the college and around for food. You will always have plenty of options.
UVU has no dorms but there are many available student housing options right next to the university.
UVU is a comfortable school but still retains a high standard of academics and student involvement.
Get involved and become someone better. Don't waste your time alone learn to work with and around others.
I love the comfortable and fun atmosphere that the university provides. Social activities are always happening. And the staff is caring and helpful.
pageTitle: Utah Valley University Reviews: Student Reviews and Ratings | Cappex
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {891188=© 2015, Cappex.com, LLC, 851650=It isn't too bad. I paid $2600 for this semester and the last 2 semesters were also about the same price., 268577=Most classes were pretty easy. The only really difficult class was physical science 1000 and it was mainly because the professor was really old and confusing., 11354=I ended up having to take a year off to get Utah residency because out of state tuition was so expensive, but after starting school here, I can tell you it was way worth it. I'm a full-time student and my tuition ends up around 2400 after my class and lab fees. And it's worth every dollar. I am learning more than I am paying., 449873=I really like how close this college is to my home. It would be easy access and it offers classes I believe I would enjoy taking. I look forward to attending this school in the fall of 2013., 479389=May be it's just me, but having roommates can be a bit of a hassle. Some roommates are responsible and others may not, but to bad you have to suck it up. Because you can't afford something better for yourself., 47581=A lot of the classes are really great. I would suggest that Music Majors don't seriously look at this school. The music program isn't very good. Beware! The Biology 1010 class is the most flunked class at the school. Taking lab is optional, but I highly recommend that you take this at the same time. It will help significantly., 797581=Probably one of the cheaper universities in the state of Utah. Tuition my last two semesters was around 2500-2700., 3655=First of all, this HAS to be one of the least expensive schools in the US! My tuition is usually around $2500 a semester, but that's for 19 credit hours... For 9, it's more like $1200. But think of it this way: Not only are you paying for an instructor, you're paying for a friend, and possibly a future reference/stepping stool into the career of your choice... It's not half bad.}

textAfterTable: Categories Comments Great for these types of students Athletes, Mormon religion and people that want a city type school with tons of things to do on the weekends. Tips for prospective students Make sure that you at least spend a weekend in Orem and take a look around campus. The area surrounding the school is great and make sure you get the input from students that are of the Mormon religion and not. And see what is right for you. Bang for the buck The out-of-state tuition is somewhat reasonable for the education that I am receiving Am enjoying being here The culture is somewhat different than what I imagined but I like the school and the people I meet. Am learning a lot My teachers are very helpful with any questions I have on a subject and really make sure that I understand what I am learning. Login to rate or flag the reviews Natasha from Orem, UT 01/15/2010
